title: Schmale Runde Grotesk by Bauer & Co
content:
dear typophiles

in a specimen book by Bauer & Co, Stuttgart (1600 pages - wonderful!) i found a font called "Schmale runde Grotesk" (Condensed round Grotesk). i digized some glyphs from a photo of a copy, some lines arent vertical and so on… its just a first test.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131013221726im_/http:/typophile.com/files/runde_grotesk_1_2_4149.png)

i have two questions regarding this font.

- the library wasnt able to date the book, but i'd like to know a circa date - so here the clues i have: on the bottom of each page, H. Berthold AG is noted beneath Bauer & Co - Bauer was bought 1897 by Berthold, as andreas mentions [here](http://web.archive.org/web/20131013221726/http:/typophile.com/node/17643). AG is shown beneath Royal-Grotesk, so i guess it was after 1908 (in the same post as linked above, andreas states that theinhardt was bought 1908). any idea?

- is there a reason for the very thin connecting parts in a, d and n? this feature is found in a, b, d, h, n, m, p, q, u.

thanks for your help!
author: thierry blancpain

comments.content: What about the upper-case letters ?——those are indentations placed at the intersection of two strokes or a departure from the intended shape of a stroke near the intersection of two strokes of a glyph to provide compensation for ink bleeding or plugging during printing or overexposure from a photographic process.

_What about the upper-case letters ?_

Right. The principle is not applied consistently in the original design, or in the digital copies shown.  
Why don't you have a go at applying the ink-trap conceit to the upper case Thierry, rather than just parrot the past?  
Some original digital faces with an "ink trap feature": Bradlo, Amplitude, Chunkfeeder.

\> Bradlo, Amplitude, Chunkfeeder.

But all of those use traps (actually the third uses thorns, not traps) in a decorative way, not for actually fighting gain.

In the case of Schmale Runde Grotesk, I have a feeling those weren't "real" traps either (not least because the caps don't have any trapping). One should look at a range of point sizes for clues.

hhp

thanks martin, i didnt know this font. i found this specimen at the libary of HGKZ (university of applied sciences and art, zürich), close enough to lineto. it seems like a direct digitalization of the font, so what i had planned doesnt make much sense anymore.

so nick, yes, maybe your idea could be something innovative instead of repeating what martha strutteregger did with it. i'll think about it.

alessandro, none of the UC-letters show inktraps. but, @hrant, as i found this specimen in a specimenbook (printed), i can be pretty sure that they were not intended as inktraps - because they're a feature of the design, not a necessity of the design itself. they're too extreme to be just inktraps. and they're featured in all sizes. as soon as i get a good scan of the original page, i'll post it. right now at home i only have copies of the book.

This is  
Schmale runde Grotesk  
A.-G. für Schriftgießerei und Messinglinien  
Offenbach am Main  
Erstguß 1885/86  
Hausschnitt

Source: Seemann, Handbuch der Schriftarten, 1926

I am sure its the font you are looking for.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131013221726im_/http:/typophile.com/files/runde_6377.jpg)
  
Georg

Re. Chunkfeeder -- my semantic slip, I was actually thinking of what Trapper (also by Jim Grieshaber) looks like, but gave it the wrong name. Which is strange, as the topic is trapping! -- I can only conclude that Chunkfeeder is a much more interesting name and got "trapped" in my memory, whereas the name Trapper makes me think of Davy Crockett, not type. Trappist would be a cool name too, and I would think of a monk ... reading in silence.

Trapper? There was a guy in M.A.S.H. called Trapper, was'nt it?
